data.name: MITM - Steal the credit cards
data.description: # Background story You work as a messenger for an online store. Every day you deliver sensitive data between the customer and the vendor. Your salary is very low and when you discover a security hole in the communication, you decide to steal the customers' credit cards for a better lifestyle. However, in order for your actions not to be noticed too quickly, the whole system should still work smoothly and the order should go through as usual. # Technical details If you have no idea about asymmetric encryption, you should do some research first. The communication between the customer and the vendor goes like this: - Customer asks for the vendor's public key - Vendor hands over his public key - Customer sends his credit card encrypted with the vendor's public key - Vendor decrypts with his private key and debits the money - Vendor thanks the customer for the purchase Implement a class `Forwarder` with methods `forwardMessage()` and `getCreditCardInformation()` `forwardMessage()` has two parameters: a `message` and a `receiver` who should receive the message. You can send a message to the receiver with the `.send()` method. ```javascript receiver.send(message); ``` `message` is an object with three properties: `info`, `publicKey` and `encrypted` `info` stores general information about the message as string `publicKey` is used to transport publicKeys (if there is no public key attached to the message it is `null`) `encrypted` is used to transport encrypted data (if there is nothing encrypted it is `null`) `getCreditCardInformation()` should return the credit card number in plain text, after you found a way to break the encryption # Some details of the encryption - RSA - 2048 modulus length - pkcs1 type - pem format - RSA_PKCS1_OAEP_PADDING padding - sha256 oaep hash - base64 encoded
